pros: Was a great company to work for.
The supervisors recognize good workers and are friendly and approachable. Most of the employees take pride in their work. The company's headquarters location is well organized.
cons: Occasionally, EMTs have to work beyond their scheduled shift, up to four hours if necessary. Low pay to start out. A small few paramedics take their job too seriously and, as a result, they do not  take assistance from EMT-Basics; instead, they try to do everything themselves.

pros: The management team is interact and supportive from the CEO down. If you are seeking a firm with fine people, skilled and educated professionals who are committed to their mission, care about their clientele and what they are doing day to day, this is the place to work.
cons: They might benefit from more emphatic controls and a system of/departmental review of what different departments are doing week to week/month to month with quality control and operational enhancement in mind, including reviewing every 2-4 weeks progress, accomplishments, issues between departments.

pros: You mainly do hospital discharges, very little dialysis runs. You don't have a supervisor constantly breathing down your neck for the entire shift.
cons: The pay is horrible, probably the worst in the state for EMS. Administration does not care for their field employees.

pros: It was an easy place to work.  Not too many hassles and a $200 bonus for any weekend shift,
cons: Equipment and vehicles were not in the best shape.  Big Con: Going out of business in March 2020.

review_title: Not too bad, except for the pay.
pros: If you do your job it’s a decent place to work.
cons: The salary is terrible. Monoc has one of the worst Per-Diem pay rate in the state. The union is an absolute joke. I would honesty feel better using the $18 a paycheck as kindling for my fire place.

pros: Some decent partners who know their stuff, ability to get a lot of urban EMS experience, almost always overtime available.
cons: Overworked, underpaid, some real lazy partners, almost always overrun, up and down the state all shift cause the company covers ~13 counties. Don't dare get injured, the company will instantly try to toss you.

pros: One of the larger and well-known EMS companies in NJ. Can transition easily into their medic program. Uniforms look nice. Good health insurance.
cons: Low starting salary. Small raises if any. A lot of dissatisfaction with management.

pros: Flexible hours and great co workers.
cons: Horrible management that micro manages everything. Horrible vehicles to use for patient transport. Management treats you like dirt and will work you like a mule for their sole benefit.

pros: Growth opportunity,  Good opportunity for new EMTs
cons: Poor raises, failure to give sufficient information about patient transport
